SUMMARY: REQUIRED | OPTIONAL DETAIL: ELEMENT

util.properties
Annotation Type Property

@Retention(value=RUNTIME)
@Target(value=FIELD)
public @interface Property

Apply this annotation to fields which you need to load from or store into .properties files.

Example usage: 

 class Account {
     @Property
     public String name;
     
     @Property
     private Integer id;
     
     // Automatically used by Property (see getter()):
     public Integer getId() {
         return id;
     }
     
     // Automatically used by Property (see setter()):
     public void setId(Integer value) {
         id = value;
         notifyAllThatIdChanged();
     }
     
     ...
 }

For a list of supported field types, use PropertiesHandler.getSupportedTypes().

Author:
Louis Acresti
See Also:
PropertySetter, PropertyGetter

Optional Element Summary
 java.lang.String defaultValue
           Set this string if you want this property to be optional.
 java.lang.String getter
          Set this string if you are using a non-conventional getter name.
 java.lang.String name
          This is useful only if you need a property to appear with a custom name in the properties file.
 java.lang.String setter
          Set this string if you are using a non-conventional setter name.
 

defaultValue

public abstract java.lang.String defaultValue

Set this string if you want this property to be optional.

When PropertiesHandler.applyProperties(java.util.Properties) is called and this property is not defined in the specified properties file, then this string (defaultValue) will be parsed.

If this string is not set, it defaults to "-required-" which is used internally by PropertiesHandler to throw a PropertyMissingException if such a property is not defined in the properties file when being loaded.

Returns:
the default value, if any, that the property should have when set in a .properties file
See Also:
PropertyMissingException
Default:
"-required-"

name

public abstract java.lang.String name
This is useful only if you need a property to appear with a custom name in the properties file. A good example is for those following a naming convention that doesn't make sense in a properties file (something like "m_SomeMember" might make more sense as "someMember" in the properties file). By default, this string is set to "-inherit-" which is used internally by PropertiesHandler to signal that the name should be identical to the field that this annotation is being applied to.

Returns:
the name of this property as it appears in a properties file
Default:
"-inherit-"

getter

public abstract java.lang.String getter
Set this string if you are using a non-conventional getter name. A conventional name is based on the name of the property and uses the camelCase naming convention like so: 
  getterName = "get" + propertyName.substring(0, 1).toUpperCase()
                   + propertyName.substring(1);
By default, this is set to "-guess-" which is internally used by PropertiesHandler to signal that the method Here's an example of a valid "guessed" name: 
 class MyClass {
     @Property
     private Integer someIntegerValue;
                
     public Integer getSomeIntegerValue() {
         return someIntegerValue;
     }
 
     ...
 }
And here's an example using this annotation parameter for a field that follows a different naming convention: 
 class MyClass {
     @Property(getter="getSomeIntegerValue")
     private Integer m_someIntegerValue;
                
     public Integer getSomeIntegerValue() {
         return someIntegerValue;
     }
 
     ...
 }
If the name you provide does not resolve as a publicly-accessible member method that that takes zero (0) arguments and returns a non-void value, PropertiesHandler will throw a PropertyInaccessibleException for the offending property.

Returns:
the name of the getter (accessor) for this property; default is "-guess-" (see above)
See Also:
setter(), PropertyGetter, PropertyInaccessibleException
Default:
"-guess-"

setter

public abstract java.lang.String setter
Set this string if you are using a non-conventional setter name. A conventional name is based on the name of the property and uses the camelCase naming convention like so: 
  setterName = "set" + propertyName.substring(0, 1).toUpperCase()
                   + propertyName.substring(1);
By default, this is set to "-guess-" which is internally used by PropertiesHandler to signal that the method Here's an example of a valid "guessed" name: 
 class MyClass {
     @Property
     private Integer someIntegerValue;
                
     public void setSomeIntegerValue(Integer value) {
         someIntegerValue = value;
     }
 
     ...
 }
And here's an example using this annotation parameter for a field that follows a different naming convention: 
 class MyClass {
     @Property(setter="setSomeIntegerValue")
     private Integer m_someIntegerValue;
                
     public void setSomeIntegerValue(Integer value) {
         someIntegerValue = value;
     }
 
     ...
 }
If the name you provide does not resolve as a publicly-accessible member method that that takes one (1) argument, PropertiesHandler will throw a PropertyInaccessibleException for the offending property.

Returns:
the name of the setter (accessor) for this property; default is "-guess-" (see above)
See Also:
getter(), PropertySetter, PropertyInaccessibleException
Default:
"-guess-"
